Don't buy this game. It isn't a good introduction to strategy (nor is it fun once you realize you have zero sway in anything that matters), unless all other strategy games are plagued with these nonsensical issues.

* Have a rested general with troops to repel an attack

* Reload

- Late game parliaments decisions tend to reward less research points

Playing as Arslan II – The Game of Princes will only allow you to play part of the overall map where all three characters were displayed. The map consists of seventeen kingdoms. Arslan II is the son of Mesud I who’s the ruler of the kingdom Sultanate of Rum, which lies roughly in the centre of all the kingdoms.  

The date is August 1174 and Kilij Arslan II has been brought back home after spending time in Mosul. Arslan II thinks he’s about to inherit the throne from his father. However, Mesud I had heard about Arslan II loitering outside the inn and whistling at women, smoking shisha with hoodlums and signing all day and night instead of doing his studies. Your first mission is policing the armed rabble within your capital Iconium. Before you can put an end to the rabble causing trouble in your capital, you’ll first need an army. To do this you’ll need to select Arslan II’s icon in the bottom left hand corner. This is where any generals you’re in command of are available to you, currently there’s only Arslan II. Once selected a small window will appear, here you’ll find information on that general. The information on the General consists of Class and Level, their Religious Belief and where they are Native from. Your general’s icon displays the types of army under their command, any perks and their mood. You will also find Mosque, Inn, Commence, Police, Repair Walls, Rest along with Barracks, Granting Gift and Dismiss.

To begin with you have a couple units of Infantry, the units are far from elite units, more like peasants and farmers. With your armies selected you may want to train them if you have the gold, this will turn your Infantry to Veteran Infantry. After which the Train button will change to Tier Upgrade, this will cost some Gold and Sugar (for infantry, other units have different requirements). When tier upgrading a unit, sometimes you’ll have a choice of unit to create such as, a veteran slinger can be upgraded to either an Archer or Crossbowman. 

In combat your General is on the left side of the battle screen with your enemy on the right. Along the bottom of the screen you’ll find options to move forward, back and stop with other options as you research them later. Using the forward, back and stop to command your units into battle, you can also swap the positions of your units in battle. Is this game a masterpiece? A South Korean studio making a game set during the Crusades, a game that suddenly came out of nowhere? To be honest, I expected a trashy shovelware product. I was wrong.

It is a cute grand strategy game with a lot of charm. While it may not always fully reflect historical events, it is far more complex than it looks at first sight. You have to manage your kingdom, including your generals, your cities, your army, the church, the state treasury, the diplomatic relations with your neighbours, a rather long research tree and additional events that happen all the time. While there is humor all over the place, this does not make the gameplay oversimplified. Quite a few options at any time, but only limited resources to carry them out make you think how to spend your turns wisely. One turn takes a month, and you can order your generals (who work as peace-time governors) to do something, but most of your orders take a month to fullfil.

There are scenarios to play, or you can take over a kingdom in free play mode and do whatever you want. I'd strongly recommend to play the tutorial scenario first to learn the basic mechanics. This is not a short tutorial, so don't expect to finish it in 10 mins. Taking over the role of a young prince who's only good at wasting his father's money on wine & women, your father gives you a little kingdom to restore order and prove yourself worth of becoming Sultan one day. Or maybe he just wants to get rid of you and assumes you will be hanged soon anyway. While there is a complex strategy game underneath, the scenario includes a ton of humorous conversations that made me smile far more than you usually do during a strategy game. At first your character has absolutely no idea how to rule a kingdom (like the player), but your advisors gently point out what you can do and what not, and you are not allowed to behead them because they are installed by your father.

When you have recruited and (hopefully) trained military units, battles may occur, and even they are not as simple as they look from the screenshots. Different unit types, unit strength, morale, equipment, training and of course your orders on the battlefield decide the outcome. Don't expect Total War complexity, but it is more than just starting a battle and sitting back and watching.

Fans of grand strategy behemoths like Europa Universalis IV or Crusader Kings II may be underwhelmed (but still enjoy this different approach to the genre), but for non-hardcore strategy players the game has a lot of things to offer. A complete and pleasant surprise. "What is this? A cute looking strategy game with potatoes? Maybe I should check it out and get a refund before I hit the two hour wall?" Thirty hours later, I keep telling myself "Just... one... more... turn" as I make my way through my first free mode campaign.  

It's a simplified empire builder with a dash of a-historical silliness. The art style gives life to the game. The characters, especially the generals and advisers, have great looks and expressions. which makes them all feel unique despite being rectangles. No blood patch or DLC here for the tactical battles. instead you get to see cute potatoes make a rubber ducky sound when they die. It all looks pretty simple at first and the initial scenario does a good job of walking you through the game without feeling like a boring tutorial (thanks in part to your leader being a young incompetent fool). 

And yet, behind the cute art and simple mechanics lies a pretty ruthless world. Going to war is a huge drain on resources. Unless you can quickly capture a capital city, expect every fight to be a drain on your treasury and your war machine to halt to a grind unless you planned ahead. Those awesome high level troops that chop/shoot/charge/heal really effectively? Well they also come with expensive needs when you ask them to storm a city and when they recover afterwards. The basic units and their more advanced versions don't have a ton of variety (infantry, shooters, cavalry, healers), but there is plenty there to play with and it makes unique units that you get from your alliances or other means that much more special.

I enjoy the mini-games for things like research, goods for sale, gambling, etc. If you really want to try and focus, you can manage to get good results when the coin flipping game comes up. But even if you fail, an overall sound strategy will mean that over the long run luck only plays a partial role (in other words, it did not make me swear at the RNG gods).

The diplomatic interface is simple but I like it. Tooltips will give you good info and so far the AI's diplomatic moves make sense. Not once have I wondered why someone declared war on me (the curse of most 4x games). Religion complicates the picture, as sometimes your natural adversaries and allies are not what religious affiliations would prescribe. This may mean risking excommunication as you try to unify the Holy Land, leading to all sorts of morale and loyalty problems among your population and generals.    

The English translation of the game is not great, but it's functional and manages to carry most of the intended humour. It's made by a small Korean studio, so I'm already grateful that there is a translation at all. The interface is not optimal but it's not horrible either. You quickly learn that Ctrl is the magic key to speed everything forward (even the opening animation before you hit the game menu).

I would heartily recommend this game. It's great fun and very reasonably priced. Although it will take many hours to really appreciate the game in all its complexity, a quick first spin should tell you if this game is for you or not.

67032987.review:
Part CK2/Total War, part Mario RPG, Plebby deftly straddles the line between depth & accessibility.  Contains all the pillars of big-boy strategy titles...diplomacy, trade, research, army composition, etc.  Then injects quick & fun mini-games into the mix (tile matching, etc.) that are novel without being overbearing.  Battles play out in real time with a side-view push/pull mechanics between opposing sides as you shift your unit types offensively & defensively.

Sports striking art & animation, with satisfying menu navigation that pops with life.  The game has a charming look & feel that you just don't see much in a genre that's typically so self-serious.  Special shout out to the extended Scenario mode where you play as 3 different rulers in a sort of extended tutorial/story mode.  The emotive characters & writing are absolutely hilarious.  Feels way more fleshed out than I expected and completely won me over.   Great learning curve to boot.  The only ding I would mention is that occasionally the translation is spotty (dev team is Korean).  Nothing egregious, but you notice it once in a while.

Overall it feels like a lot of thought and TLC went into this production.  It's way deeper than it looks on the surface but at the same time is refreshingly approachable.  Big thumbs up.

67028138.review:
Really nice and fresh take on strategy games.

You play as one of the factions roughly based on countries and factions of middle ages. You get generals, fill them with units and try to conquer the map. Battlefields are horizontal with your and enemy units going from one side to another in a tight group of 1-5 units and trying to defeat the other side. Defensive side gets some towers and walls while attacking side gets siege equipment. You can send commands to your troops using pigeons and control the battle while standing on the far side of the battlefield.

There are few minigames to gain extra resources - throwing a coin to get better medal or some cash, slots for some resources or a great "Thank you for donations" letter, codebreaker to hire generals or remove rebels, match 3 for research, etc.

There are plenty of different units separated into infantry, cavalry, ranged and healer types (maybe there are more, but I didn't see them yet), there are units unique to some factions.

Overall it feels like the game was made by people that love it.

This was a real pleasant surprise. I bought this purely because the art style was appealing, without really looking into what the game was like. This was a gamble, and I'm happy to say that it was a gamble that I won.

Plebby Quest will feel very familiar to people who have played Koei's Romance of the Three Kingdoms games. There is a real emphasis on making good use of your limited actions each turn. Each general can take a single action every turn, making the campaign a matter of careful management of your action economy. Generals have a limited number of carrier pigeons, which limits the number of orders they can give at once in battle. You've got several resources to manage. Diplomacy, religion, loyalty and morale, there is plenty to consider.

Don't let the cutesy graphics fool you. There's plenty here to keep strategy fans happy. The fact that it's adorable is just a plus.

Other people compared this game with other Grand Strategy titles such as Total War, EU4 and CK. It is comparable but do not expect the same depth. PQTC is made for people who are not familiar with strategy games, but that is not to say a veteran won't enjoy their time. I personally had fun in my 24 hour play time and I would recommed this to pretty much everyone. Here is a little summary about the game:

--Good--
The artstyle and animations are just lovely, never got bored looking at them.
Even though PQTC is not a very deep game, it has everything other big titles has from trading to research. Just a bit more simplified.
AI is not completely clues and makes moves which makes sense, kinda.
Music is pretty energetic and feels good.
--Bad--
It lacks some basic features such as improving the settlements.
AI is too defensive, I went to war with 20 factions and I had 1-2 attacks to my settlements in any given turn. Just dominated them one by one.
Not all factions are playable, there are around 10 factions in total that are playable. That looks alright but there are more than 40 factions in the game. I can understand why they didn't put some of them because there are hopeless factions that just can not survive but I wish we could played with more factions.
When you end your turn, the game becomes hold Ctrl and spam Enter/Left Click. We should be able to skip the turn of other factions faster.

In the end if you are new to the strategy genre or a veteran who wants to play something more casual, this game will please you.
